item.title: Probability - Packet 02 1
item.description:
Precise abstract concepts of outcome, sample space, event, and probability measure help clarify the assumptions in our probability models. An event is a description of something that can take place. An outcome is a complete description of something that can take place. All outcomes are events. Typically an event is only a partial description. An outcome is an event of the finest grain. After an event takes place, the fact that it took place constitutes information. Information is given and received by communicating the fact that an event took place. The set of outcomes, also called the sample space, is a set of complete descriptions of all things that can take place. An event is a subset of the set of outcomes. Infinities Difficulties with infinity and the continuum mean that sometimes a wild subset is not a valid event. Notation Write for a typical set of outcomes, for a single outcome. Write or for typical events. Write for the collection of all events. An outcome is considered an event by considering instead the singleton subset that contains just that one outcome.Outcomes and events Flip a fair coin two times. A sample space for this experiment is the set . An outcome such as or means that the first flip is heads and the second is heads (as in ) or tails (in ). Note that a single outcome includes the result of both flips. There are more complex events, such as . In words, is the event that the first is heads, the second is heads or tails. (Technically: first heads second heads OR first heads second tails.) Monty Hall In our version of the Monty Hall game, an outcome is a complete description of a run of the experiment. For example: “Martin first chose Card-3 = Goat-2, then the host revealed Card-2 = Goat-1 and offered a second choice, then Martin switched and received Card-1 = Car.” On the other hand, “Martin was offered a second choice” defines a (complex) event. Technically this event is the subset of all complete outcomes in which Martin was offered a second choice. Given two events and , we can form new events: is the description: “event or event ”. is the description: “event and event ”. is the description: “not event ”. Events are mutually exclusive when they do not have any outcomes in common. Events are exhaustive when they cover all outcomes between them. Logic operations Set operations In the mathematical formalism, events are sets, and the logical operations “or”, “and”, “complement” become: the set union. the intersection, also written . the set complement. The union, intersection, or complement of any pair of events is another valid event. We can think of these set operations as giving event operations that produce new events from given ones.Infinities If there are infinitely many events: every countable union or intersection of events is a valid event. Technical , empty set, is called the null event. , subset of, says that every outcome in is also in . Events are mutually exclusive when . Events are exhaustive when . (These properties can be applied to more than two events.) We write for the number of elements of (or when it’s not finite). Relations Set union, intersection, and complement satisfy rules. Two of the rules are followed also by addition and multiplication, so they are said to give an algebra structure to events: Associativity: . Distributivity: . Events also satisfy: De Morgan’s Laws This means: you can distribute “ ” but must simultaneously do a switch .Composite experiments and conditional probability trees A pharmaceutical experiment involves trialing Drug and Drug and Placebo on male and female lab rats. A rat is chosen at random from a collection housing males and females. This is the first part of a composite experiment. Then a drug is chosen and administered. This is the second part. The composite experiment can be described by a tree: There are paths through the tree, and each path is an outcome of the experiment. One could add a third component, the result in the rat (Good or Bad). The new tree would describe 12 outcomes. Roll a die then flip a coin Riley rolls a fair die twice, and then flips a coin. Describe the sample space of this experiment. How many outcomes does it contain? Role a die then flip some coins Savannah rolls a die. If the outcome is even, she flips a coin. If the outcome is odd, she flips two coins, and records heads if there are two heads, otherwise she records tails. Describe the sample space of this experiment. How many outcomes does it contain? Counting outcomes: permutations and combinations In a lottery, five distinct numbers are picked at random from . How many possible outcomes are there: (a) If we care about the order of numbers. (b) If the order does not matter. Cardinality of an event Each of 3 people flips a coin and rolls a die. The sample space can be modeled by . There are total outcomes in this space. Let event be given by “the number of heads and sum of die rolls is even”. What is ? This event is the intersection of “even number of heads” and “even sum of dice”. The former has 4 elements. For the latter, here is the distribution of number of ways to get a given sum: So there are ways for an even sum, and we have . Each event is associated with a probability of its occurrence, which is a quantity representing its degree of likelihood.The meaning of this quantity is the subject of controversy. Classical theorists hold that probability derives from the symmetry of a situation (dice, coins, poker) Evidentialists hold that probability relates known evidence to a proposed hypothesis Bayesians hold that probability measures the degrees of belief of persons Frequentists hold that probability derives from the pattern in repeated trials Propensity theorists hold that probability measures a causal power or tendency inhering in objects A probability measure is a function , is the collection of events (including outcomes as singletons ) is the real numbers, such that satisfies the rules: for each , “non-negativity” , “normalization” when , “additivity” where the last rule applies to countable collections too: These rules are called the Kolmogorov Axioms.The collected data of a sample space , a set of subset events , and a probability measure , taken together as an ordered triple , is called a probability space.Consequences Decomposition: find exclusive and compute instead of . Negation: compute instead of . Monotonicity: if then . Inclusion-exclusion: even if are not exclusive, you can take instead of . Inclusion-exclusion This is a useful counting principle, and it applies to probabilities because of additivity: An extended version works for three events: Further extended versions work for more events.Probability Venn diagram At the university, 25% of students wear a watch, 30% wear a bracelet, and 60% wear neither. What is the probability that a randomly chosen student is wearing either a watch or a bracelet? What is the probability this student is wearing both? Probability intersection theory Suppose and . Show that . This is equivalent to assuming that each outcome is equally likely.Counting outcomes Problem: A fair coin is flipped four times. What is the probability that the first and third flips are heads? Solution: There are total outcomes. The outcomes may be written as -tuples with either or . Write for the event containing the -tuples with and anything else. Then by counting, . So . Exclusive OR Problem: The professor chooses three students at random, one to be Host, one to be Player, one to be Judge. What is the probability that Lucia is either Host or Player? Solution: The number of ways Lucia ends up Host is and the number of ways she ends up Player is also . The total number of outcomes is . Lucia cannot be Host and Player, so they are exclusive events, and we use Decomposition. We have: Counting teams with Cooper Problem: A team of 3 student volunteers is formed at random from a class of 40. What is the probability that Cooper is on the team? Solution: There are teams that include Cooper, and teams in total. We have: Haley and Hugo from two random selections Problem: The class has 40 students. Suppose the professor chooses 3 students today at random, and again 3 on Thursday. What is the probability that Haley is chosen today and Hugo on Thursday? Solution: The outcomes can be described by ordered pairs of sets each containing three elements, where contains three students chosen today, and contains three chosen on Thursday. There are possible sets for and the same number for . So there are valid outcomes. There are sets that contain Haley, and the same number that contain Hugo. (This number is equal to the number of sets of two students taken from the 39 students that are not Haley.) So there are pairs of sets with Haley in the first set, Hugo in the second set. Let be the event of interest, that Haley is included today AND Hugo is included on Thursday. The final probability is the ratio of the number of outcomes in to the total number of outcomes: Wisconsin flag A kindergarten class hangs a random state flag (50 flags) on the wall every day. What is the probability that two days out of three given days have Wisconsin’s flag? Drawing balls of distinct color An urn contains 3 green and 4 yellow balls. Two balls are drawn out. What is the probability that they are different colors? If the sample space is infinite, then we cannot generate a probability measure by counting and dividing. Usually the context suggests another natural measure.Rolling die until 4 Suppose we roll a fair die repeatedly until the number 4 comes up. An outcome is a play of this game, and is recorded by the number of rolls required. The natural probability measure comes from the assumption that in a single roll, each number is equally likely. Let be the probability of the game requiring rolls. Then: because this game is the same as the game in which we roll 3 times and ask for the odds that only the last roll is a 4. 4 will come up ‘eventually’ Roll a fair die repeatedly until the number 4 comes up, and let denote the outcome where rolls are required. What is ? Randomly broken stick Break a stick at a random location. What is the probability that the short piece is less than the original length? Points chosen in square may be close A point is chosen at random inside a unit square. What is the probability that the and coordinates differ by less than ? Exactly three events In a lottery, five distinct numbers are picked at random from . How many outcomes contain exactly three even numbers? What is the probability that exactly three even numbers are chosen? Tiling a board Tile a board randomly with nine dominoes, placed horizontally or vertically. Suppose each possible tiling pattern is equally likely. What is the probability that the middle domino is vertical? (Hint: find the solution for a board, and apply this solution three times.) (b) Compute the probability by considering the complement of the event that we did not see all three colors. Paying bill with cash, check, card A restaurant offers three ways of paying the bill: cash, check, and card. At the end of the day there were 100 paid bills. Some of the bills were paid with a mix of cash, check, and card. There are 78 cash receipts, 26 card receipts, and 16 checks. There were 13 bills that used cash and card, 4 that used card and check, 6 that used cash and check, and 3 that used all three methods of payment. (a) If a bill is chosen at random, what is the probability that the bill was paid fully using only one of the methods? (b) If two distinct bills are chosen at random, what is the probability that at least one was paid using two or more methods? Suppose a COVID test gives a (true) positive on 96% of patients who have COVID, but gives a (false) positive on 2% of patients who do not have COVID. A random person tests positive. In order to fix your intuitions, think about it this way: roughly 2.5% of tests are positive, with about 2% coming from false positives, and about 0.5% from true positives. The true ones make up only of the positive results. If two tests both come back positive, the odds of COVID are now 98%. If only sick people are tested, so that 20% of those tested have COVID, , then one positive test gives a COVID probability of 92%. You roll two fair dice, and tell me that the two numbers are distinct. What do I estimate for the probability that there is at least one 6? Boy Girl Paradox You are going to meet the king. Along the way, you are told that he has one sibling. What do you estimate is the probability that his sibling is a sister? The formula was taken as a mathematical definition.In reality, one can give preliminary conceptual definitions to each of these terms: is the probability that event takes place, given the knowledge that has taken place already is the probability that event “ and ” takes place is the probability that event takes place With these as philosophical definitions, one must find additional justification for the identity . This identity, once made, immediately gives Bayes’ Theorem.Justifying Bayes’ Theorem One type of justification is that if a gambler updates his or her degrees of belief using Bayes’ Theorem and the axioms of probability, he or she will avoid a “Dutch Book”, i.e. a collection of bets that leads to sure losses. However, it is not necessary to follow Bayesian updating to avoid Dutch Books consistently. Bayes’ Theorem can be written in a slightly different form: Here we interpret: is the prior probability of some hypothesis is the probability of some evidence is the posterior probability of given the evidence This version of Bayes’ Theorem can be interpreted as an update rule, i.e. a rule for updating probability estimates. If you have some hypothesis , and you gain new, relevant, evidence , you may wish to know how to adjust your estimate of the likelihood of . This rule says to multiply the prior by the ratio . The numerator: how likely is evidence given the hypothesis? The denominator: how likely is evidence , period? If the ratio is high, the hypothesis strongly boosts the likelihood of ; Bayes’ Rule then says the appearance of boosts likelihood of by this same ratio.“The factor by which makes more likely equals the factor by which makes more likely.”Bayes’ Rule and symmetries The Bayes’ Rule exhibits a symmetry: and are treated on the same footing mathematically. In the real world, is typically data, while is typically a theory or explanation. Or again: in the real world is usually made first, and comes after. The latter ordering is reflected also in the multi-stage experiments where comes first, and second, and Bayes’ Rule is typically used to assess based on and simple calculations of . This is weird! Why does a “theorem” with perfect symmetry arise only for applications with notable lack of symmetry? Is Jack left handed? At some point during a criminal investigation, Detective Inspector Morse is 60% convinced that Jack is guilty. Morse then finds evidence that the suspect must be left handed. It turns out Jack is left handed! (Note that 20% of the population is left handed.)
